content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
Half-Life 2: Episode One 1 was released a bit over 8 years ago, as the even then long-awaited expansion of the original, critically widely acclaimed game. Since it is part of the Orange Box, the Half-Life 2 Complete Edition and the Valve Complete Edition, chances are great you already own and have played the original Half-Life 2.The good news: Episode 1 continues on the high level of level design and gameplay the original had set. There is however an important shift in focus, as the greater part of the game is played alongside Alyx, Gordon's female companion-in-arms. Alyx happily stands her own against the enemy hordes and doesn't need any sort of "babysitting" games wtih less well developed AI sometimes call for. She's been updated graphically as well (looking even better ;-)) since Episode 1 makes use of the High Dynamic Range lighting effects first tried out by Valve in Half-Life 2: Lost Coast. However, compared to that playable tech-demo, environments in Episode 1 are a bit disappointing and don't always offer the best opportunities for the upgraded engine to shine. There are no wide-open vistas, and although the opening level in the Citadel is impressive, it also has a sort of repetitiveness that comes to the fore now and then.On the other hand, gameplay-wise everything is as top-notch as it was in the original game, and the fact that you play alongside Alyx offers some interesting opportunities. There's even a Steam Achievement called "One Bullet" which gets unlocked by playing through the entire game (!!) using one single bullet. The rest of the kills/actions has to be made by using the Gravity Gun, which gets an upgrade during the early part of the game. This calls for clever thinking, and I tried to get it, only to find myself missing the shooting action after a couple of hours ;-).All in all, Episode 1 is a good to very good expansion, continuing the story of the original game in a logical and interesting way. There's no reason at all not to give it a shot (...) when you've played the original Half-Life 2.Overall rating: 8/10

Posted: January 4, 2015
												Episode One picks up the story right around where Half-Life 2 ended.  Alyx and Dog are looking for you, and your job is to get the hell out of City 17 before it blows up.  There are a few enhancements to the gameplay, some new enemies, and a superb storyline that continues to expand the Half-Life universe.  A must play if you are a fan of the series, or if you're looking for a quick shooter.  The game itself is not long, but packs a punch in the short campaign that you play.

												In one way this is the worst of the Half Life franchise, but that said the Half Life series is one of my favourite ones and I still highly recommend this Episode.You got nothing new from the moment you left your Buggy until the end of HL2 in this Episode, so a bit of "platform strategy" or vulgo "recycling" as we sadly know to well from other sequels, but still enjoyable.There are not many novelties, but the ones like the "Zombines" and flares are welcome and add well to the existing HL2 world.Graphics are defo a step forward compared to HL2. As far as the story goes, this is really just a connection between HL2 and Episode 2 and nothing terribly new or exciting will be revealed, but by no means boring.You got a bit of citadel and super gravity gun action, combined with a hint of Ravenholm in the dark, Sandtraps w/o pheromones and lots of City 17. Buy it.

Posted: October 31, 2015
												Half Life 2: Episode One is the direct sequel to Half Life 2, but is it worth the name ?Half Life 2: Episode One begins as soon as Half Life 2 ends. We find ourselves in a bad place as the citadel is about to be destroyed and it's gonna take the entire city with it, so you need to escape before the city is destroyed. This review will be incredibly short since this is pretty much Half Life 2, I'll just cover the cons and pros of the game.I want to say this was a bit disappointing playing this episode. Apart from the final mission, the entire game is kind of boring. The gameplay is the same thing as in Half Life 2. There's no change whatsoever. There's nothing really new here it's basically the same game as Half Life 2.The story is still great. But I think the events leading into what is Episode Two are far more interesting than the entire story of episode one.My biggest problem with this game is probably the story. The game is kind of slow in pacing and it's a drag and not to mention it's also incredibly short. It took me 2 hours to finish the entire game. There's pretty much no replay value after that. Overall my feelings towards this episode are still positive. This is as good as the previous Half Life titles, just the story is kind of boring, but apart from that it's a great game.Final Rating:7/10 - Play itIf you liked this review please consider giving it a thumbs up and if you disliked the review post in the comments on what you disliked.For more reviews follow Snort's Review curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
-Quick Review-Half-Life 2: Episode One was Developed by Valve Corporation and released 2006. Not much changed from Half-Life 2, this game is a continuation and starts right after the events of Half-Life 2.


Half-Life 2 - Uploaded for the review 
A Screenshot of Half-Life 2: Episode One
By: Atratzu




-Detailed breakdown review-Story: After the events that took place in Half-Life 2, Gordon and Alyx Vance are reunited and need to escape City 17. Unfortunately, they cannot escape before the Citadel's core detonates. So Alex and Gordon are forced to enter the Citadel to stabilize the core long enough for them to safely escape.


Story Sample - Uploaded for the review 
A Screenshot of Half-Life 2: Episode One
By: Atratzu




Gameplay: There are only two changes to the core game: First, Alex's AI has been dramatically improved, so she is more helpful and not nearly as annoying as most NPC's that simply repeat the same phrases and actions. Second, you start the game with the Gravity Gun, which is utilized both in combat and puzzle solutions.


Combat - Uploaded for the review 
A Screenshot of Half-Life 2: Episode One
By: Atratzu




Achievements: There are 13 achievements in Half-Life 2: Episode One. Five achievements are unlocked by just completing the game, the rest are achieved by special circumstances. (like... “beating the game firing exactly one bullet”, “not killing any stalkers”, or “killing an elite soldier with his own energy ball”)To be honest, these achievements aren't very bad, this was a relatively easy 100% completed game, compared to others games.Price: Half-Life 2: Episode One, is priced at $7.99, unfortunately the game is very short, and this price is a bit high for the amount of time it will take to play through the game. (You will probably spend about 5 or 6 hours to beat it)A far better alternative, is to purchase The Orange Box for $19.99, you will purchase: Half-Life 2, Half-Life 2: Episode one, Half Life 2: Episode Two, and Portal.Conclusion: Story: Still very good, but unfortunately much shorter then Half-Life 2. Gameplay: Pretty much the same as Half-Life 2, the only difference is you use the Gravity gun much more, and much sooner. Achievements: Straightforward, fairly obtainable 100% completed game. Price: Over priced, wait for a sale, or purchase the Orange Box for the best value.I recommend this game to anyone who played Half-Life 2 and wants to continue the story of the Freeman...Related reviewsHere's the URL to see my review for  Half-Life 2Here's the URL to see my review for  Half-Life 2: Episode TwoHere's the URL to see my review for Half-Life 3 ...(...is what I would say if it was released yet *sob*)

number of helpful: 11 of 11 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
												Half-Life 2: Episode One begine right where Half-Life 2 ended, and continues the story of Dr.Gordon Freeman in City 17, however, this time, the priority remains to escape the city following the events of Half-Life 2.With updated lighting and AI for deuteragonist Alyx Vance, and expanded usage for the Gravity Gun, Half-Life 2: Episode One continues Half-Life 2's usage of advanced graphics, physics, music and writing to create a game that is both rich in gameplay, plot, and emotion. Like its predecessor, it uses training techniques to allow for a more fluid experience, and utilizes the game's physics engine to a full. With excellent performances by its cast, it's able to greatly explain the story of Gordon and Alyx escaping City 17.With an excellent soundtrack composed by Kelly Bailey, the game becomes even more action packed, and the act of blasting zombies in an infected hospital with a shotgun becomes far more enjoyable, and the scene of fighting infected Combine soldiers in the underground becomes more threatening.The game also includes Developer commentary in the form of a commentary mode that allows the players to listen to the developers' thoughts on everything from map design to character and scene writing, and includes all variant of Valve Employee sharing their thoughts on the game.If I had to say I had any issues with the game, I'd have to say that it's fairly short, while Half-Life 2 is around 12-15 hours long, Episode One is around 5 hours long. That's not to say it's a bad game for that, though, as the story and game runs at a certain pace that allows for it to be enjoyed to the fullest; Replaying the game with the knowledge of how short it is doesn't damage or reduce the enjoyment of playing it, as Valve injects a great deal of fun into the game so there aren't many moments or time that is wasted, and every minute is used to its fullest.If you enjoyed Half-Life 2, and want more, I greatly suggest you buy the Half-Life Complete Steam bundle, preferably during a Steam Seasonal Sale. The bundle consists of this game and every other Valve-released Half-Life title, and is an essential for a fan of Half-Life.

Milestones In Gaming Never Get OldThere is not a lot left to say about HL2. We all agree that it lifted the genre to the next the level. I have to confess however that I haven't played HL2 Episode One at all during the last 9 years and that I did not even touch it during the last 4 years that I have it in my library.  THIS WAS A GREAT MISTAKE AND I REGRET ITThis 9 year old Stand-Alone Expansion of HL2 is perfect: story, characters, puzzles, innovation, action, design and even the graphics are still on a very high level and way ahead of some newer games. And it runs like butter...New features like VR or 3D Vision lift HL2 in general into the new age of virtual reality, of gaming. I played it with 3D vision and had a great blast wandering through City 17, the Citadel. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED! If you have it in your library since a long time, but never touched it, never installed it - like I did. Do not wait any longer. 9 years have been enough. GREAT GAME.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												Half-Life 2: Episode One is science fiction first person shooter game developed by Valve Software on the Source Engine. It tells the continued story of physicist-gone-action-hero Gordon Freeman as he and action-hero-gone-love-interest Alyx Vance escape from the physically unstable City 17 before it blows up I think.In my review of Half-Life 2 I definitely wasn't very nice to the game. I said the game was unfocused and average, with interesting ideas and clever storytelling but drawn-out setpeices and a largely uninteresting plot if you remove all that glittery facial animation. Some of that, I think, is still justified but one thing I forgot to mention was how much I actually really like Half-Life 2.One thing the HL franchise enjoys doing is pulling the rug out from under the player and then throwing a bunch of enemies at them. That's pretty cool but it's also sort of troubling, considering that most of Half-Life 2 feels very aimless as if Gordon is just drunkenly stumbling between ambushes and set-peices. Episode 1 seemingly tries to fix that by making whatever the current goal is very obvious, either with some kind of environmental clue or with Alyx directly telling you what the objective is:Escape the towerGet to the train stationThe story is more grounded and because of that the gameplay can throw you into as many accidental circumstances and detours as it wants because you always end up back on track. I also appreciate how the stakes are a lot higher feeling in this game. It isn't just a vague intergalactic business proposition between Breen and some alien terrorist people, the actual city feels like it's about to blow up and if you keep getting interrupted by the combine than everybody involved will actually die. And it isn't just your life that's at stake here, you spend the entire game fighting alongside Alyx Vance, which sounds like a bad idea but this game manages a sidekick-idea very well.Anybody who played the first game remembers the third act where you command a squad consisting of that guy who sounds like everyone else and a girl who only occasionally dreams of cheese(?) but nobody WANTS to remember that part because not only is it sandwiched between the two best parts of the game but it also is un-doubtably the worst. The AI blocks the player at every turn and is super reliant on Gordon; they will not go anywhere unless you ask them too and they die as quickly as your enemies do so they may as well not be there--heck the game is more fun when they AREN'T there.The squad idea comes back in Episode 1 but not only are they more resistant, they seemingly abandon the whole "Targeting" thing--they seem to go wherever they want until you start to progress, and most importantly they stay out of the players way. All of this culminates into Alyx who not only follows the player from the very start but is INVULNERABLE to damage. This could make her too powerful but the devs fix that only giving her a pistol until about halfway through, and even before that she's a very good aim. Most of the opening is spent with the player under a variety of handicaps such as only having a gravity gun or not having a ton of ammo and the devs cleverly use Alyx as your second half, which not only ties their mostly plot-based comradery into the gameplay but also makes you feel like a real team by the end.Ultimately I think Episode 1 expands on HL2 and makes the game better. There's only one new enemy and a smaller arsenal than before but the gameplay is tightened and the story in more investing. I'll be the first to admit that my review of HL2 was a bit hyperbolic but I still recommended that game and I absolutely recommend Episode 1 as well

content:
Posted: November 13, 2012
												Half-Life 2 Episode One is the continuation of the Half-Life saga or rather the story of how Gordon Freeman saved the world. While I was a big fan of the single-player campaign in the original Half-Life these new stories that have been unveiling beginning with with Half-Life 2 just haven't been quite as impressive and Episode One feels much the same way.The story picks up shortly after the end of Half-Life 2 proper. Through the power of being the protagonist you have somehow manged to survive and must now fight your way out of the city before it implodes on you. There is not much new to the storyline or gameplay and the areas feel like they could have been ripped straight out of the regular Half-Life 2 campaign.Of course there is a certain bias from me because I never bought Half-Life 2 to play Half-Life 2, that was just a nice little bonus, I bought it for the mods and as such I am not nearly as invested as others in the lives of Alyx and her boytoy Gordon.Get it if you liked the single-player campaign in Half-Life 2 and want a few more hours of it. Otherwise you can safely ignore it as it's an entirely forgettable expansion.

Posted: January 9, 2016
												The story of Half-Life continues in Episode 1, right after Half-Life 2. Gordon and Alyx have to escape City 17, but not before containing the Citadel Core.The game is a lot shorter and doesn't have as much content. Over the course of it, you acquire all needed weapons to complete it. You will still fight ships and striders though. Puzzles are pretty much what you would expect from a Half-Life installation. Whole game can be completed using only the gravity gun, because you are always with Alyx and she's able to do the shooting instead of you.Nothing new is added, except maybe a new zombie, no weapons, no vehicles, but it doesn't really matter, because continuing the story is more important. If you liked Half-Life 2, then you should also probably buy Episode 1.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												The Half-Life 2 episodes were meant to be a foray into a new method of game development. Instead of spending several more years making Half-Life 3, Valve would release smaller iterations over shorter spans of time, which would also let them refine their work as they went. Coming out two years after HL2, Episode One was a relatively understated success, with improvements made in AI and the Source engine taking the technical spotlight.It's not nearly as long, dealing primarily with the aftermath of HL2's finale, but in the process avoids the drag that game sometimes suffered from. There's a decent variety here: the first third of the game only gives you one weapon to work with (albeit a powerful one), the second third is almost survival horror, and the final third is a roaring return to Combine-destroying action.You're partnered the entire time with Alyx Vance, who is thankfully more helpful and humorous here than annoying, and it's with that you realize that Valve also meant Episode One to be an exercise in character development that did more than just have you stand around for 5 minutes every time an NPC opens their mouth. The game is largely a success in that department too, and Valve's signature stealth brilliance in writing manages to make her not only cool, but human.If you're reading this, you probably already own it, but if you don't (or do and haven't played it for some reason) and were a fan of Half-Life 2, I'd say go for it. At the very least, it's a good bookend between its predecessor and its more outstanding sequel, Episode Two.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2016
Half-Life 2: Episode OnePositives• Beautifully put together story• Story progression is well paced and exciting• Characters do not feel static• Graphics are still good even for today's standards• Organized and reasonable achievements for the most part• Simplistic and engaging combat• Well put together environment and futuristic theme• Music fits right into the storyNegatives• AI is a little outdated • Many times I did not know where to go or what to do• Quite a few times the game left me stuck where I had to restart a segment• Story still has holes by the end hopefully filled in by Episode 2• The "One Free Bullet" achievement is very frustrating where I had to replay half the game to get• Puzzles can be annoying at times• Physics are inconsistent sometimes• Ends in yet another cliff hangerFinal Thoughts: Episode One wraps up quite similar to the previous game with a cliff hanger where you do not know if Gordon survived or not. It also starts with holes not filled and hopefully is filled in by Episode 2. The story is very well crafted but this episode does not do much in the way of the story it just continues the last game. Although there was a few problems with segments not working and the "One Free Bullet" achievement being a hassle, the game is definitely worth your time.Rating: 8.0/10-Penta

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
												I bought this game years ago simply to see the ending to the cliffhanger that Half Life 2 provided. And I utterly hated this game, at the time I thought everything was poorly designed with my main complaint being the lack of ammo and weapons for the amount of enemies you have to kill. I considered it one of the worst game I ever played and it turned me off of Half life so much that I didn't bother buying the 2nd episode. I still haven't played it and I'm planning on buying it tomorrow during the Holiday Sale.But after completing Half life 2 with some mods I decided to install episode one again and take it for a spin, fully expecting to hate it again. I was pleasantly surprised though Episode one is still the weakest game in the Half Life Franchise. First off my initial complaint of the lack of ammo for your weapons just... isn't a thing anymore. Maybe I just sucked and wasted too much ammo but I never had a problem. Though I wish that the crowbar was given to the player in the beginning of the game, instead of the half-way point where you no longer need it. Having a viable melee weapon early on in the game against the headcrab zombies would have been really nice instead of having to constantly run around the map looking for cement blocks to shoot at them with your Grav Gun.Also the game is really dark, this in of itself isn't an issue but due to the fact that your flashlight uses energy you basically have to stop and stand still in the dark for a few moments while your flashlight charges, which really kills the game flow for me. I wish they just made the Flashlight not use your suit's battery so it could stay on indefinitely.I also really liked the Zombine enemy. They become a priority when dealing with hordes of Zombies and they can be actually quite helpful for you when they pull out a grenade and go kamikaze. If you're quick enough to get away they can  usually kill the horde of zombies for you. You can also shoot the grenade out of their hand or snatch it from them with the Grav Gun. It's all these things that makes them a fun dynamic new enemy which makes up for the lack of new weapons or features.There are also a lot of great gunfights with the Combine and the firefight in the Hospital is definitely the best part of Episode one. Also Alyx is a treat too though I found her animation to be a little stiff and lifeless at times. Beat the game and when you're on the train, just look at Alyx and you'll see what I mean. She looks like a Mannequin at points and for a game whose main selling point is having Alyx fighting with you it seems like a big oversight, especially since the source engine has proven before that its quite good at making life-like animations. But the biggest problem I have with the game is that it is waaay too short. I have around 6.9 hours clocked in and thats after 2 playthroughs. I believe my first playthrough took me about four hours and my last playthough just shy of three. Even in a market in which single player campaigns are getting increasingly short, there is no excuse for Episode one to be this short and it is simply not worth the asking price of $8, even when you take mods like MINERVA into consideration.Ultimately I would recommend Episode One but with a big asterisk: Do not pay full price for it and understand that it is the weakest game in the Half Life Series, even a game like Blue Shift I feel is better than Episode one. But it has some cool gunfights and helps to continue the story and transition into Episode two. Pay at most $4 and make sure you play the Minerva mod at some point to get your full money's worth.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26
 Half-Life 2: Episode 1 After the success of HL2, Valve made the design decision to release its sequels as episodic titles. This allowed them to capitalise more efficiently on rapidly improving graphical technology and dispense their content a lot faster. Released in 2006, Episode 1 is the direct continuation of HL2 which charts Gordon and Alyx’s treacherous escape from City 17. Technically, it attempts to improve and advance every aspect that its predecessor established.The gameplay of Episode 1 is based almost entirely around the concept of you working in partnership with your AI companion, Alyx. This mainly involves Alyx following your lead and helping you during combat, but there are also several innovative sections which reinforce the idea of teamwork. These include a dimly lit area where you need to use your flashlight to illuminate enemies for Alyx to shoot; and a section where you need to clear Alyx’s line of sight while she supports you from afar with a sniper rifle.She has been programmed to act as a support role, remaining reticent during puzzle sections and hanging back during ‘boss’ encounters. This feels like a well-balanced design choice as it allows the player the freedom to advance at their own pace and feel more of a sense of accomplishment at overcoming challenges.The AI has seen significant improvements, especially in path finding abilities. Alyx in particular has had a substantial upgrade, giving her new animations for crouching and synchronised kill moves for a lot of enemy types. Enemy AI has also seen developments as Combine soldiers can now crouch and take cover more effectively. They have also been given a rope repelling animation which always looks visually engaging. The only new enemy type introduced is the Combine zombie, or ‘zombine’. They are an entertaining addition that adds a new threat to the undead portions of the game.The puzzle sections are still relatively easy and should not take anyone too long to solve. Despite this, they are slightly more diverse than the simple physics based puzzles of the original game and still serve as an effective diversion from the combat scenes.Graphically, Episode 1 has seen some major upgrades. Valve has adapted their Source engine to include new developments in HDR (High Dynamic Range) lighting, which was originally showcased in their Lost Coast tech demo. This really helps to elevate the presentation to a high standard; for example the shader effects used around the Citadel core still manage to impress me today. There have also been further advancements in facial expression modelling which helps bring some more personality to the main characters.Overall, Episode 1 is a solid entry into the HL2 series. The main criticism that can be presented is its length; it is only five chapters long and can be comfortably completed in less than 10 hours. However, it is worth mentioning that there is also a developer commentary mode which provides some insightful observations if you are at all interested in the design process, or if you simply want to get a little more replay value.Personally I feel that Episode 1 provides the least story enhancement of the series, which can make it feel more inconsequential. However, from a technical stand point it does improve on almost every aspect in terms of gameplay and graphical experience, and is a well-polished presentation that serves as a good stepping stone into Episode 2.

content:
Posted: February 26
 Half-Life 2: Episode 1 After the success of HL2, Valve made the design decision to release its sequels as episodic titles. This allowed them to capitalise more efficiently on rapidly improving graphical technology and dispense their content a lot faster. Released in 2006, Episode 1 is the direct continuation of HL2 which charts Gordon and Alyx’s treacherous escape from City 17. Technically, it attempts to improve and advance every aspect that its predecessor established.The gameplay of Episode 1 is based almost entirely around the concept of you working in partnership with your AI companion, Alyx. This mainly involves Alyx following your lead and helping you during combat, but there are also several innovative sections which reinforce the idea of teamwork. These include a dimly lit area where you need to use your flashlight to illuminate enemies for Alyx to shoot; and a section where you need to clear Alyx’s line of sight while she supports you from afar with a sniper rifle.She has been programmed to act as a support role, remaining reticent during puzzle sections and hanging back during ‘boss’ encounters. This feels like a well-balanced design choice as it allows the player the freedom to advance at their own pace and feel more of a sense of accomplishment at overcoming challenges.The AI has seen significant improvements, especially in path finding abilities. Alyx in particular has had a substantial upgrade, giving her new animations for crouching and synchronised kill moves for a lot of enemy types. Enemy AI has also seen developments as Combine soldiers can now crouch and take cover more effectively. They have also been given a rope repelling animation which always looks visually engaging. The only new enemy type introduced is the Combine zombie, or ‘zombine’. They are an entertaining addition that adds a new threat to the undead portions of the game.The puzzle sections are still relatively easy and should not take anyone too long to solve. Despite this, they are slightly more diverse than the simple physics based puzzles of the original game and still serve as an effective diversion from the combat scenes.Graphically, Episode 1 has seen some major upgrades. Valve has adapted their Source engine to include new developments in HDR (High Dynamic Range) lighting, which was originally showcased in their Lost Coast tech demo. This really helps to elevate the presentation to a high standard; for example the shader effects used around the Citadel core still manage to impress me today. There have also been further advancements in facial expression modelling which helps bring some more personality to the main characters.Overall, Episode 1 is a solid entry into the HL2 series. The main criticism that can be presented is its length; it is only five chapters long and can be comfortably completed in less than 10 hours. However, it is worth mentioning that there is also a developer commentary mode which provides some insightful observations if you are at all interested in the design process, or if you simply want to get a little more replay value.Personally I feel that Episode 1 provides the least story enhancement of the series, which can make it feel more inconsequential. However, from a technical stand point it does improve on almost every aspect in terms of gameplay and graphical experience, and is a well-polished presentation that serves as a good stepping stone into Episode 2.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												This is the epilogue to Half-Life 2, and it plays well.  You can see the Portal-like thinking in the design, especially at the beginning areas, which are a bit puzzle-based rather than combat heavy.  The difference is rather than using a portal device, you are using the gravity gun.  You don't even start with a crowbar.  Of course, this is just while the game prepares to return to form.  By the time it's over, you'll be back with crowbar in hand and a full array of weapons.  As well as the return of Gordon's followers.The game emphasizes the follower/NPC mechanics, as not only will Gordon have NPC followers helping him through parts of the game, but Alyx follows him for most of the game.  Rather than being a burden to be protected like too many escorts, however, Alyx is an active combatant, and more than holds her own.  You'll be glad she's there to draw fire and take down enemies at your side, and you'll notice the few times when she's pulled away to perform a background task and you have to go it solo.  It is a little abrupt, but it is worthy appendix to Half-Life 2's gameplay and storyline.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2010
												Not my favorite episode but still, getting the Gravity Gun in the Citadel is still worthy and because you're a lucky dog with Alyx next to you.In reality, the ending of Half-Life 2 is kinda tweaked. G-Man was putting you back to your lethargy when Vortigaunts appeared and saved you from this fate. Now in a City 17 in ruins, you have to go back inside the Citadel to buy time for the evacuation of civilians, though Combines are still fighting till the end.It's not my favorite episode because there is nothing new and that we already saw City 17 or the Citadel. It's just that I wanted a change of scenery, like Episode 2 proposed. But Alyx is now really at your side every step of the way, which is also a good change.The new enemy here is the Zombine: a soldier from the Combine being affected by an Headcrab and which often is carrying a grenade. I don't count Stalkers here as they're victims first and that they're not trying to kill you, they're just following a pattern with the laser.Also, the real intense moment is probably the train station: whether it's escorting civilians to safety or deal with the Striders to make sure the last train can depart (and it's yours, so...).The real challenge was added in 2010, with the achievement asking you for using only one bullet (and that bullet is necessary because without it, you can't advance in the game).In other words, missing Episode 1 can't be possible for the sake of the story and the plot, otherwise, for me, it's not a memorable one. Episode 2 was better as Half-Life 2.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												I can now understand why Alyx Vance has been hyped up as a great partner over the years. I didn't get the feeling of her having much of an influence in the base game of Half-Life 2, but in Episode One she really shined while saving Gordon's bacon repeatedly. The entire game sends dedicated to showcasing her as a strong partner, the likes of which has only really been rivaled by Elizabeth from Bioshock Infinite in recent years.The gameplay continues to be innovative, mostly by expanding what the NPCs can do, like having Alyx gun down everything in sight with a pistol, sniper rifle, or shotgun. It's a fun little continuation of the main game, although I can't say that it adds much to the story, which will hopefully be revealed in the second episode.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
OverviewAfter the major success that Half-Life 2 was, many fans of the series were left wondering when the next installment of the Half-Life franchise would come out. It came as a shock when Valve announced that they would begin releasing episodic installments in their best selling franchise.Half-Life 2 Episode 1 is a continuation of Half-Life 2, picking up right where the last game ended instead of starting somewhere completely new. This may confuse many new players who haven't played the original hl2, but overall episode 1 is a nice bridge between Half-Life 2 and Half-Life 2 Episode 2.Pros Picks up right where hl2 left off, no time jumps Alyx's ai is very good for a game that is 9 years old, still works almost flawlessly. Game runs very well, very little lag and no crashes Game looks great, a few graphical updates from hl2 The soundtrack is very well done, the tracks flow very well with the gameplay.Cons The only setting in the game is City 17/the Citadel. Nothing we haven't already seen in hl2. The only new enemies are the Zombines and Stalkers.  The zombines are plentiful in numbers and are fun to mess around with, but the Stalkers don't even fight back and serve little to no purpose in the game. The game is quite short, even if it is supposed to be just an episode. You might finish it in an afternoon or two. Rating There is no denying that this is a good game. However compared to Half-Life 2 and Episode 2 this installment seems to be missing what made those 2 games masterpieces. You should definetely buy this game, and it is definetely worth 8 bucks. Just keep in mind that it doesn't bring a whole lot of new things to the table like the other ones did.8/10

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Half-Life 2: Episode One is a pretty good continuation of Half-Life 2. The game picks up the story from the point where Half-Life 2 ended: Gordon and Alyx are saved by the mysterious alien creatures (who are our allies here, altough we battled them - among other things - in the first game) both from the explosion and from the unpleasant guy in suit. What we get from here is an action packed escape, much like before, but this time with more zombies and almost completely set in the well known city environment. The finale may not seem as grandiose this time, but the final train ride is amazing.In addition to improved lighting, I noticed the particle effects (almost as good as in F.E.A.R.) looking better than the ones in the original game. It's visually striking how the light shines through the grains of dust.Gordon is accompanied by Alyx throughout the entire game and it is quite refreshing (the dialogues are pretty one-sided though, because Gordon still remains silent and fails to react to anything she says :)) to have her around, after the solitude of the original game. Alyx can still die if we don't pay attention, but this time she's more capable of defending herself.We have the same enemies (expect more zombies, antlions and striders) and weapons as usual (for me it wasn't an issue since I think the weapons are versatile enough), altough we can use the gravity gun more often - the environment is full of heavy, usable objects. As a matter of fact there is an achievement called 'The One Free Bullet' for which you can fire your gun only once throughout the whole game (the rocket launcher does not count as one, but the pistol, shotgun and machine guns do), that one time being crucial (you have to shoot a padlock to advance further). Attaining it may seem hindering, but it's quite fun and not as hard as it sounds.The main problem however arises from Half-Life 2: the story, or rather the lack of it. You still won't be able to find out anything about what's going on, moreover there are new mysteries as well, for example the huge, amorphous creature we meet at the beginning (seemingly using some sort of psionic attacks). For someone who values storyline above almost anything else in a single player game, this counts as quite a big mistake.After all the game is still great, but Valve should have given at least a bit more answers instead of extending the core Half-Life 2 getaway gameplay with a few more hours. Talking about hours, the game is also pretty short and can be finished in about 6 hours (took me less than 13 hours with all achievements attained). I don't think that it's such a big problem however, since it wasn't priced as a full game at it's release. It feels a bit like a link between the original Half-Life 2 and Episode 2, but I'm not saying it should be given a miss. On the contrary, you should definitely play it as it's still a great game and has some memorable moments (make sure to listen to Dr. Kleiner's speech on the menu or ingame via the city screens :))PROS+ improved lighting and particle effects+ having Alyx as a sidekick is fun+ combat is still great, fighting striders is thrilling+ some very creative achievementsCONS- story is still functional, no explanations- setting is motonous- a bit too shortRATING7.5/10

Posted: January 8, 2012
												As Crab said in his recommendation: "Nothing happens in this game... I mean really you can skip it." Of course there is a grain of truth in that statement, when held in the light of Episode 2 or even Half-Life 2, Episode One leaves much to be admired. This can be attributed to the games eco-centric location throughout the ruins of City 17 and the Citadel and the lack of varying companions throughout the game. While doing an excellent job making Alyx seem like a more believable character with well scripted combat sequences and animations you can't help but feel that she's holding your hand through it all. Personally I loved EP1 because the raw urban combat of the final levels of Half-Life 2 were my favorite levels, and Episode One extended on that making for an entire game focused on the best part of HL2. All that being said it's not imperative that you play it, and you can go from HL2 straight to EP2 without worry about missing on vital story points.

Posted: March 16, 2014
												The sequal to what I consider to be the greatest game of all time, and it is still pretty good. I liked to think of Episode One as the middle child of the Half Life 2 trilogy. It doesnt really do anything that unique, but is still a very interesting and able game. Most of the enviroments are tight, so its a lot less open world compared to Half Life 2. The absolute best part of this game is the realtionship between Gordan and Alyx. Watching her interact with you is simply amazing. Valve actually made me genuinly care about a character, something very few have. This game only lasted about six or seven hours, but is still a worthwhile experience. Pros:+Everything Half Life+Lighting+Character connectednessNeutral: *Narrow enviroments*The "Middle Child" syndromeOverall: 9/10 If anything, you basically need to play this just to get the amazing Episode Two. Its still good in its own respect, but forgetable overall comparted to the other parts. Do not buy this on its own, get it bundled in the Orange Box.

Posted: January 4, 2014
												If you finished Half-Life 2 and wanted some more, then this is the game for you.  Episode One kicks off directly after the events of Half-Life 2 and despite being just a little bit short, the excellent story, game play, audio and visuals continue as well as some small improvements that can be seen if you are paying attention.  It belongs to Half-Life 2 and this should be played as soon as that title has been completed.

Posted: September 1, 2011
												I know that a lot of people were disappointed by this installment, but I had a hoot playing it. It's been a secret fantasy of mine to be part of a mass exodus out of a doomed city my whole life. I think my secret desire to make such an escape started with a Fourth of July celebration my parents took me to when I was three. These visions of hundreds of people and shimmering explosions in an unfamiliar urban setting stuck in my tiny baby brain and have been with me my whole life. So you can imagine my surprise when over a decade later I'm reliving these memories as I flee City 17 in much the same way I imagined myself all those years ago.This has left me to assume Valve has access to the Jungian archetypes of my mind.

Posted: November 16, 2012
												Episode 1 teaches the player to learn to co-op with a skilled NPC, yes, of course, it's got that intense feeling of how much City 17 went through after the Citadel's destruction at the end of Half-Life 2. Half-Life 2: Episode One is a first-person shooter video game, the first in a series of episodes that serve as the sequel for the 2004 Half-Life 2.The game stars immediately after Half-Life 2. Gordon Freeman wakes up near the Citadel after Alyx Vance and Dog find him. Gordon and Alyx travel through the City 17 to find train to escape city...VERDICTPros:- Great story.- Excellent voice acting.- Great characters.- Awesome musicCons:- Game has 5 chapters, it is too short.8.5/10

Posted: August 4, 2013
												In an attempt to reduce production time (that apparently didn't work :P), the rest of the story for Half-Life 2 was broken into an episodic structure. This is episode one. It is shorter, but still just as sweet.This continuation of the FPS Half-Life 2 is just as well done. The same interesting characters, shocking events and horror atmosphere pervade. The same enemies and variety of tools are there. It's just more of Half-Life 2, and, like before, it ends with unanswered questions and begs for more.

												Half Life 2.... did you like the story, and gameplay to Half Life 2, you will like Episode 1. It is a continuation to the epic story from Half Life 2, and Half Life 2 Episode 1.Pros.-Great graphics considering its age (over 10 years old)-runs great even on low end machines.-epic story-good weapon selection-good AIcons:my main gripes about Episode 2 is the same as Episode 1, do not take this as a do not buy this however. I bought this game again even though I own it already on XBox 360 and played through it again here. I love this game :).-In Episode 1 there are no new weapons.-In Episode 1 the story length feels short (the episodes are however cheaper than the base game)-No full controller support (This game does not work with a controller like with the 360.) It is not a big deal, but to say partial controller support is spinning the truth. You cannot celect all of your weapons with a controller. This seems like something that could have been fixed with a patch.All said and done I did play this with a keyboard and mouse. IT was a blast, and the computer version was converted to use a controller (even if with poor support,) so playing with a keyboard and mouse like old school games is no big deal. If you do not already own this game BUY IT, YOU WILL NOT REGRET IT.

Posted: January 10, 2016
												Half-ife 2: Episode One is an Action, FPS, Singleplayer game that is a great add on to the rest of Half-Life 2's story, for all you Half-Life 2 fans.All though Half-Life 2, Ep.1 is a short game, it really builds on the story of Half-Life 2, by telling what happened after the defeat of Dr. Breen. The game adds some new features, like flares and and using cars to stop Antlions from spawning in, while retaining all of the machanics from Half-Life 2. Because this game is still made by Valve, the game can be difficult at times, and you might need to take a step back, and try the area a few times, before getting it right, just like games such as the Portal franchise, and, of course, Half-Life 2.Overall, this game is a great game. I really had fun playing it, and recommend to every Half-Life 2 fan out there, who wants that extra amount of gameplay from the franchise.

Posted: April 26, 2015
												Half-Life 2: Episode One is the first story-driven expansion for the original Half-Life 2 by Valve. Taking play mere minutes after the end of the first game's campaign, it follows the effort of both Gordon and Alyx as they try to escape City 17, where the collapse of the Combine Citadel is about to set off a huge explosion.As far as gameplay goes, nothing really changes from the main game, aside for new situations you have to face with the instruments you are given (one sequence, for instance, requires you to shine your flashlight on enemies to help Alyx killing them while you don't have weapons to speak of). Alyx will accompany you for the whole episode and fight alongside you.As a downside, this time around Gordon isn't as effective as in the original Half-Life 2: you spend the first half of the game armed with your gravity gun only and generally you unlock other weapons at a slow pace. While this forces you to relay on the environment and your creativity more, it can get annoying during particularly hard sequences.Half-Life 2: Episode One is roughly three or four hours long and takes places in environments you already got yourself familiar with, but still it expands nicely on the original story and keeps the gameplay fresh enough

Posted: May 19, 2014
												Half Life 2: Episode One is short, sweet and very enjoyable.Despite the age of the title, the graphics are still attractive by today’s standards, gameplay is great and the story paves the way for the next chapter and leaves you eager to play episode 2.The game does not take more than a couple of hours to complete, but it is time well spent. If you enjoy games not just for the story but also are an achievement hunter, then you can gain 100% of the in-game achievements with relative ease in a single play through. If you own Half Life 2 I recommend adding this to your steam list.

												Half-Life 2: Episode One is in essence, more Half-Life 2.The only issue I had with Episode One was it's short length, lasting maybe 3 hours at best. Time to get all the achievements should be around 3 hours if you do them all in one playthrough, or 6 if you do it twice.In conclusion, you should buy it just for that reason. Posted: December 6, 2014
												Half-Life 2: Episode One is the first of the two episodes that take place after the end of Half-Life 2.After an ending oddly reminiscent of the first game, we are once again left on a cliffhanger after the events of Half-Life 2. This game is the continuation of Half-Life 2, and once again we take control of Gordon Freeman on his unstoppable killing spree.While Episode One is very short in comparison to Half-Life 2, it still holds the same level of quality in terms of gameplay. The same characters are there, and a few new enemies and mechanics are introduced. None of this is exactly game-changing, yet it does keep it fresh. The story lacks a little, which is mainly due to the lenght of the game.There isn't much to say for Episode One that hasn't already been said for Half-Life 2. While it is fun to fight alongside Alyx, it doesn't quite make up for the length of it. If purchased through the Orange Box, it isn't much of a problem.Overall, definitely worth playing, but only as part of the series, and not on its own.

Posted: January 24
												This game is of course a follow-up on the Half-Life 2 adventures, and what exactly happened after the tower ending in which there was no conclusion to in the main installment. This exact episode will take you through the story about the escape from the great area (and tower) before it explodes completely, which would mean the death of Freeman, Alyx, and pretty much everyone in a great scale area, so it is about escaping ASAP. Afterwards it will take you through the pressing task of saving as many remaining citizens as possible from City 17 before the - again - explosion. Essentially, it is all about escaping City 17. A must if you´re a fan of the series. This episode in particular is only really challenging in the end when it starts firing all sorts of enemies at your face, but is fairly casual-friendly up until the ending chapters - at least on normal and "expert". Well, not so much on expert. ;)Have fun!

Posted: March 28, 2014
												Sadly, a very short expansion pack to perhaps one of the greatest FPS games of all time. It is somewhat of an aftermath game as it picks up Gordon's story immediately after the ending of Half Life 2. Gordon and Alyx are separated and in the first part of the game your job will be to find Alyx again then the two of you can continue your journey and fight against the Combine.Other than the usual high production value you can expect from a Valve game there's no new asset here. There are no new enemy types, no new weapons, no new characters introduced. It is not necessarily a problem if you loved HL 2, however, later on they released Episode Two with enhanced graphics, new enemy types and some really good new ideas.Anyway, I am biased here as I love everything that's Half-Life. I hate Valve for not releasing the final episode as with Episode 2 they could not conclude Freeman's story. If you loved Half Life you can pick the two expansion packs labelled as episodes when they are discounted.

Posted: January 16
												not gonna lie; this is THE WORST hl2 episode. there's only two, so i'm not worried about this being an insult. although, if you didn't know that there's not a third episode, then you probobly have bigger problems. Compared to half life 2 and hl2;ep2, this game isn't quite up to standered. The game's pacing isn't too good, there are a few intresting mechanics, but as valve admits, they didn't have enough time to do what they wanted with said ideas, and it shows. The good news is; if this is what happens when valve is rushed, then that's pretty good. it's hard to get all the plot, (more of a pacing issue) but i deffinatly enjoy the more plot-dense story, and other adjustments an episodic format brings. Being half-life, this is a must-play, and a promising expansion of half-life 2, even if the much-awaited sequal is... well, AWAITED. 9/10

content:
Posted: September 28, 2016
												Half Life 2: Episode One while a very short game it is still a great 'short game' to be played. If you want more juicy details check out my Half Life 2 review for more information. Anywho. Let us get the elephant out of the room. This particular episode tries a little bit too hard at what it wants to be. Is this still an action adventure game? Is it a science-fiction horror FPS? The reason why I say this is because unlike in Half Life 2 where the sections are spread out. The "chapters" jump from one genre to the next with really no breather for the player. And I guess you can say it's because of the "intense" circumstances of the story. But still, Episode One could've used more chapters to spread things out rather than just cramming it all in.The story obviously takes places just hours after the events of Half Life 2. The overall goal is to get out of City 17. That's basically it. You get some "new" 'plot questions' in this particular game. But these 'plot questions' won't be explained until Episode 2. And even then, the new plot questions you encountered in this game and in the next episode won't be REALLY answered until (Half Life 3) <- Lol. I recommend this game. But! And this might be a hard pill to swallow. But, I think Episode One and Two should've just been in the ACTUAL Half Life 2 game rather than spacing the game out. It might've been because of budget or giving players a breather. If that's the case then they should've made Ep 1 and Ep 2 into purchasable expansions rather than actual 'full games'. I recommend buying the Orange Box rather than the games seperately btw.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												I always thought "Half-Life 2: Episode 1" was a strange name for the continuation of the plot of Half Life 2 and a little undeserving in my opinion. After the hanging thread in Half Life 2, you progress the plot as Gordon Freeman once more to escape City 17 with Alyx Vance before it's reactor goes critical. The game itself can be beat in a little under 2 hours, but it's a DLC so I'll let it slide. Oh yeah: Cliffhanger ending- Check.Pretty short review; not much to say here.I rate Half-Life 2: Episode 1 with a 7/10Wait for it to go on sale before you buy it; I don't think it's worth $8, but the choice is yours.  Until next review!Let's form up! ~Stealth 1548

												It's rather funny that I replayed this game after years, and felt that it still stood up. Everyone is worried that linear FPS story driven games are out and everyone wants BIG SANDBOXES AND TONS OF SIDEQUESTS. This is not the case, if a new game was released, within the same style of ALL THE OTHER HALF LIFE GAMES, it honestly could go either way.I feel like as a huge fan since the 99' title, that I can safely say that's what most of us want. More of the same gameplay, but more to the story. That's what makes half life great y'know?I digress, great game, great series. If you haven't played it what the hell is wrong with you?

Posted: March 5, 2012
												I just beat it for the second time. I had beaten Half-life 2 again yesterday (I don't ever replay games) and I thought I was going to leave it at that. But no; I still wanted more Half-life greatness. So I moved onto Episode One, and now I expect myself to be replaying Episode Two as well.Episode One starts minutes after the ending of Half-life 2 and Gordon Freeman continues on his journey to fight the powah, with Alyx along with him/you. This is much shorter than Half-life 2, being an "episode", but there is a lot more Alyx time in this one, which is a good thing since she has a very good AI and makes for a great partner in the game. So many awesome setpieces thoughout Episode One, but that is to be expected from this consistently-amazing series. If you liked Half-life 2, don't stop there!

content:
Posted: July 23, 2013
												The second installation of the seemingly never-ending Half Life saga is an interesting one. Half Life 2: Episode One is by far the weakest of the series, but the game is required for the complete narrative. The game is awfully slow paced, and it really does nothing to advance the story. Since these episodic installments were supposedly to be released every 3 months, a slower first episode would be resonable, but since the saga is taking its time, its a bit of a dissapointment.8/10. Any Half Life game is great, this one just lags behind a bit.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												FOLLOW ME. SET ME FREE. FOLLOW ME AND WE WILL ESCAPE FROM THE CI-TY. Seriously though, this is amazing. It might not change the gameplay, nor the graphics. But the story, the music, and the feel is all more hectic and chaotic than the cold, lonesome, and dark feel of Half LIfe 2. It feels different, but just as good, continuing an already amazing game. It is amazing in it's own right, and is one of the few times that a DLC feels like an actual continuation of the story, and a great one at that. Altough Episode 2 is honestly "better". I love this series and you should too. Buy the game, buy the episodes. Just do it. Free humanity.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Half-life 2 Episode One, the continue of Half-life 2.. Now you will know what happen next right? Now let's review it!The Gameplay:It's still very fun, you can't go serious at this in anyway... if you're a tryhard player you will. The weapons are still the same but they're so fun messing with it.. The Gravity Gun is the most fun weapon in the game.. so please try to enjoy the game instead of being a 100% tryhard.The Graphics:It improved the graphics than Half-life 2, at least.. playing in 720p won't take it's full effect.. so I highly suggest play this on 1080p and you will see it's texture improvement.The AI's *Artifical Intelligence*:Same as Half-life 2 but the AI's are now good.Rating: 9/10Why not 10/10?, Cause I can't give a game that is 10/10..I highly suggest people buy this only for Half-life Series Fan or a FPS Shooter Fan.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												Half-Life Episode One is a blast to play. I really enjoyed it.It's as epic as Half-Life 2 is, but what bothers me is that the length is VERY short, for an explorer like me you finish this game in max 6 hours.Beside this fact i still think this is a very, very good episode. Continuing directly where Half-Life 2 left off and i think the interactions and releations with Alyx and the other charachters seems to be stronger and better then in 2.It got as usual, great levels, graphichs and more. And one hell of a cliffhanger at the end.9/10 would defenitly reccomend to play (make sure you played Half-Life 2 before playing this)

												A great game that didn't take long at all to beat. The only thing that made it harder for me was that I tried for all the achievements the first time and couldn't use a gun the whole time because I was going for the "The One Free Bullet" achievement were you don't use a gun the whole time except for one time to open a gate for Alyx. The story just added onto the Original Half Life 2. You must play Half Life 2 to fully understand what is going on in this game. The graphics are great, the gameplay was smooth and very well done. I highly recommend getting this game to any Half Life fan.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												It is a continuation of Half Life 2. Alyx teams up with you throughout the entire game, being a great companion and an efficient fighter. She will help is dispatching enemies too, though her default weapon is weak until she finds a shotgun later on. Either way, she is a great addition to the game.The game is relatively short, only lasting 6-8 hours. The achievements encourage multiple playthroughs , especially going for the near impossible One Free Bullet (finish the game firing one bullet, which has to be used to break a lock at the start of the game. You can use the crowbar, grenades, mounted guns, rockets, and of course the iconic gravity gun, one of the best weapons in any video game. Ever).Overall, while it may be shorter by  15 or so hours when compared to Half life 2, the quality is still there. You have the linear formula that made the previous game great, along with more challenge in the form of dark underground sections and strider runs.  A brilliant game from beginning to end. Like Half Life 2, I recommend this to Half Life fans and the general First person shooter community alike.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												It is a continuation of Half Life 2. Alyx teams up with you throughout the entire game, being a great companion and an efficient fighter. She will help is dispatching enemies too, though her default weapon is weak until she finds a shotgun later on. Either way, she is a great addition to the game.The game is relatively short, only lasting 6-8 hours. The achievements encourage multiple playthroughs , especially going for the near impossible One Free Bullet (finish the game firing one bullet, which has to be used to break a lock at the start of the game. You can use the crowbar, grenades, mounted guns, rockets, and of course the iconic gravity gun, one of the best weapons in any video game. Ever).Overall, while it may be shorter by  15 or so hours when compared to Half life 2, the quality is still there. You have the linear formula that made the previous game great, along with more challenge in the form of dark underground sections and strider runs.  A brilliant game from beginning to end. Like Half Life 2, I recommend this to Half Life fans and the general First person shooter community alike.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												This is an amazing sequel to Half Life 2. It is a bit shorter though, but the experience was as great if not greater. I loved the new HDR feature, the new mechanics of Alyx's combat, animations, how the things worked, the developer's commentary, 10/10 game. I have been once again amazed with the beauty of half life works. I definitely recommend this game. It's really nice! But I recommend playing the half life series all the way from half life 1 up to half life 2 episode 2, that's the best way.The gameplay is good, as always, not some simple shooter that you would find in some forsaken company.The graphics are too good to be explained with our human dictionary.The bugs... well, I have found one bug, although I am not sure if that's even a bug. So basically at the last chapter (Spoiler alert) I was taking the citizens to the trains, everything was good until one of them was stuck somewhere beside the stairs, he could move but he was killed instantly, what I mean is that he could have ran to the trains and would have got me an achievement, but he wasted it and died.Anyways, the game is just perfect. Played on the same breath.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2013
												Episode 1 is really just more of the same. It continues on from the very moment the original game finished and the player will find themselves in the thick of the action right from the start. I must admit that I thought there would be more new guns, enemies and locations in this expansion. But it appears that Valve made a decision to concentrate solely on storytelling and leading the player through a constant flow of thrilling and challenging scenarios.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												My review for Half-Life 2 can be seen here:http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198056186683/recommended/220It's good, damn good but it's not as good as Half-Life 2 or Episode 2. This has got some damn good atmosphere and combat sequnces and while short stands tall as an excellent adventure amongst FPS titles and expansions. That said it really is the middle child of the Half-Life 2 family. From replaying I've come to think it's real weaknesses come from it's exposition heavy,slow start and opening Citadel chapters. Especially when  all combined. It has you teamed up with Alyx for the entire episode and thankfully she is well written, helpful and interesting and a damn impressive showcase of AI unlike a certain Sheva. At the same time though you'll often be locked into what I call little "cutscene" rooms. YES you can move around freely as control is never taken away from the player in the Half-Life games but while these "cutscenes" as well written and interesting as they are are also unskipable and if it's not your first time playing all you can do is leap around like a fussy cat and make people look like an idiot as you attempt to jump on their head or find something to throw. The tunnels, and ESPECIALLY the remains of City 17 are when it's best. The Citadel isn't bad, FAR FROM IT, but it wasn't my favorite part on repeat playthroughs and it keeps me from speedily progressing to my favorite parts faster if I don't skip massive chunks of the gamet via chapter select that is.Episode 1 does a lot of things scripting and scenario wise that I've never seen all together in one single FPS game before especially in terms of it's design and layout but then it will repeat some of these good parts a little too much and as a cherry on top will have a character openly say "oh god no", "not again" and "here we go again" winkingly as you do a reocurring scripted sequence involving Combine, explosives and doors. Having a character remark at how over used a gimmick in game is and then DOING the gimmick anyway does not then excuse or fix the gimmick. It sticks out like a sore thumb as this sort of thing is uncommon in the game prior. It's like when Duke in Duke Nukem Forever sighed in disgust at a literal pipe puzzle and said "I hate Valve puzzles." and then proceeding to do it anyway. (And no I am not saying anything in this game is as bad as any part of the Duke Nukem Forever.)It's short (real short) but sweet and unless you don't wan't to wait forever for a conclusion after you play Episode 2 I highly reccomend you play Episode 1. My review for Half-Life 2: Episode 2 can be seen here:http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198056186683/recommended/420My review for Half-Life 2: Deathmatch can be seen here:http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198056186683/recommended/320My review for Half-Life 2 Lost Coast can be seen here:http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198056186683/recommended/340

content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												I was mixed about the original Half-Life 2, so what can I say about Episode One?  Well, it's merely more of the same...just shorter.  I bet some of you are rolling your eyes and going, "Well, DUH, that's why it's called Half-Life 2: Episode ONE!"  Well, it certainly feels as if I played the game already...which I did...and Episode One is merely the equivalent of a DLC add-on...which, given the title, it certainly is.  The game doesn't really add anything new apart from a new area to trudge through, continuing from the previous game obviously, and about one to three new enemies to shoot at for the entire game.  This is the same FPS-platforming-puzzle story I've played already, only this time it felt as if the whole thing was going in reverse.  An example would be how in the original game, the gravity gun got upgraded at the end, whereas in Episode One, it gets upgraded at the very beginning...and then it's suddenly downgraded to its usual status during the rest of the game.  I was hoping I would be able to lift and throw enemy bosses with the thing had the upgrade stayed on, but the game said no, which is still a very major flaw with this game.  Getting through Episode One literally got me through half the time it took to get through the orignal game, and that's including getting almost every Achievement.  All in all, what can I really say that hasn't been said before?

content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
												It's hard to judge this game, because it may be considered both a part of the larger HL2 story, or a standalone game, but I'll consider only the second case - players falling in the first, surely know what/why they want to play.Well, HL2E1 didn't age well at all. I've played HL2 10+ years ago, then bought the Orange box this year following the glowing reviews, but it's been a big disappointment.In order to give perspective, it's important to consider that Bioshock - which aged really good instead, was released only one year after (same as HL2E2).The story arc is trivial and short.The physics-based puzzles are boring by today's standards - pick the ball, and put it into the container, wash, rinse and repeat.The sidekick just can't stop talking.The environments are banal.If you want to play a standalone game from the past, there is much much better.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4
												I give this game a mild thumbs down. It’s sort of fun, but it’s by far the weakest game in the series. There are too many poorly designed missions and not enough variety in the scenery/activities.There is one overtly tedious mission near the start when you are trying to shoot the reactor with lasers that is just mind numbing. Also, towards the end of the game there is an escort mission that’s a candidate for worst escort mission ever. It’s bad enough, you have to ferry survivors to safety once, but for this mission you have to lead multiple groups over the same territory a half a dozen times.If you are a fan of the series, you will probably get enjoyment out of this game, I’m just disappointed that it wasn’t anywhere near as good as Half Life 2.6 /10

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												I'm between Yes and No for recommending this game. Althought this episode was a little chaotic and objectives were not very fun, I still think it is a crucial episode in the Half Life franchise.The game is good but worse than Half Life 2 in few ways. The storytelling is a little rubbish and it was more like I was watching a really long cutscene with mediocore objectives such as escorting civilians four times in a row, it felt more like a "transition" from HL2 to Episode Two. The only unique thing about fighting in this game is that it made good use of the flashlights. Lots of dark areas in this game, almost horror considering I'm arachnophobic and headcrabs scare the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of me.On the bright side, I think what this episode had done well is the relationship between Gordon and Alyx. There were many suggestive scenes and dialogues that made us feel like Alyx did have some sort of a school girl crush on Gordon since HL2. I thought this episode really gave us a chance to let Alyx blend into the story much more so her existence is a little more obvious and valuable. I really thought everything was natural and it wasn't forced, they did well on this part. So kudos to them.BUT THEN AGAINWHERE IS HALF LIFE 3

number of helpful: 3 of 12 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												Please bare in mind I literally played this for the first time today (Nov 2016).I remember everyone saying that this was the game that sculpted modern day games. Particularly FPS games. Now I understand why so many of those tedious stand and waste time moments exist in games. Half Life 2.So many times in this very short episode do you stand there watching a wheel go round slowly while you open a shutter. For no other reason than to waste our time.I enjoy the physics puzzles still. They should be used more in gaming.The AI drove me insane though! Several times I got trapped in a doorway with Alex stood behind me not moving. Where I had to load or kill myself to get free.I have no real care for anything in this world. To be honest I have almost no idea what the f*** I just did for the last couple of hours. Why does this episode even exist?You wake up. Lurch from area to area doing "stuff" and then the credits roll. That's pretty much it. The slimsy bit of story that exists kind of gets forgotten until the last scene.Maybe back in the day this was excellent but honestly this gameplay no longer stands up. The last few years we've seen the resurfacing of open world games. That is for the best. Linear♥♥♥♥♥ time wasting shooters are no longer entertaining for me.Plus since the whole "Chapter 3" has yet to emerge in any form I guess the second chapter is going to be just as pointless story wise.Yes I apreciate this is an old game but honestly I'm feeling like you had to be there nearer to its release to understand the appeal. Glad I waited for a sale to play this now.

Only play it if you don't mind slogging through the middle of the game where it's absolutely no fun at all.This game was decent.  It's a linear shooter.  It's the low point of the Half-Life series, but it still was fun until you got to the "Low Lifes" chapter.  Then, we get to fight the real enemies, not this underground-low light crap with antlion spam.  We get combines and more zombies, with Alyx usually either sniping or in the middle of a battle with you, which means no more cheesy lines from her that irritate the hell out of you.  The hospital level was perfect for getting you out of the underground crap, taking you right into where the game belongs... something reflected in Episode 2, where we didn't have that downtime where antlions are everywhere and we can't see anything.As for storyline, maybe it felt different as what "re-opened the HL series and made something out of that unresolved ending from HL2," but for me, it felt like that explanation between HL2 and Episode 2.  It would be fine as a 3-minute recap (which is in there for Episode 2, if you just want to skip over this).  It's okay.  The storyline itself is just continuing HL2 straight from the ending, where (NOT SPOILING IT) and you wake up in a junkyard where D0G uncovers you.  You go back to (NOT SPOILING IT) via junkyard car now powered by D0G's incredible hulk powers and (NOT SPOILING IT).  You end up... look, I can't tell you, it's all just spoilers.  It was okay for storyline, while adding more space for time-consuming lore that I'll never even bother to google because of my social life conflicting with spending all my time pondering the mysteries of the Half-Life franchise.Either get this game and force yourself through the middle part where the game sucks, or just skip to Episode 2, a game without any sort of "crappy section," and watch the 3 minute recap of Episode 1 complete with post processing as soon as you click new game.  The choice is yours.

number of helpful: 7 of 22 people (32%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Holy crap! Is all i can say. There is only one complaint that i have and its the AI! Oh lord! She is only good for opening doors and killing. Which in Half Life you would think is enough. But this is the first Half Life, and Valve game, where i was frustrated by the difficulty. A challenge is one thing, but this is on a whole nother level. Alyx will literally not go where i want her to go, and for some reason this game has two(maybe more) instances where you are basically at the mercy of how good and how fast she can kill things. The scenes i am talking about are the ones where you turn the wheel to open the gate. And it would not be a problem if there were not so many antlions poking you causing the gate to close.I would have thought that having someone follow you around would make the game a little bit easier, and she is pretty handy, but having her around is just a nuisance. In Half Life 2 there was a part where you "command" soldiers to navigate the streets to get to the Citadel. And just keeping them alive was a pain because they went where the pleased most of the time. But at least for them you had some sort of control. Ive found myself having to push her to go where i want her to.The good things i have to say about this game were the graphics and story. I played Half Life 2 on Xbox and on my Xbox 360.  And that game came out a while ago, so the graphics werent as sharp or at least from my experience. But wow! The graphics were amazing! This is a beautiful game.The story is great. I am already hooked and it is only the beginning stages of the game. Valve does a good job at making people want to continue the game just to find out what happens next in the story. In Half Life 2: episode one I am trying to bear the headache of having Alx join me because ever since i finished Half Life 2 many years ago I was left wanting more, especially with that ending!Overall i do recommend this game but buyer beware that it will take a whole lot of patience and a whole lot of time to get used to her. The main reason i think buyers would like this game is for the story. If you care more about the story then this game satisfies that. It is definitely a game that gamers should play at least once in their life just to experience Alyx AI

number of helpful: 8 of 24 people (33%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												Valve made a gigantic mistake with their episodic release concept. It tried to deliver content faster and it failed immensely, giving chunks that just weren't enough to please fans at the time. The cliffhanger ending didn't help either, a cheap way to end any game. Then if that wasn't enough, they stuck Alyx at the side of the player throughout the game. She becomes more of a nuisance than a welcome partner, mainly with her intimate remarks towards the player. Her nonstop presence is in stark contrast to previous titles, where the player's quest was mostly a lonely ride with only short periods where characters followed. This sense of isolation really improved the previous titles, and here I feel it was a bad design choice to stick Alyx to the player for all of the ride. I think the main reason why Alyx doesn't work, is because she ends up trying to be romantic with the player and not Gordon, as Gordon doesn't talk or have any personality, he's just a suit for the player to wear. This ends up being incredibly awkward.All in all the episodic content idea was bad, even Valve knows this. It delivered an underwhelming chunk of a game that didn't provide enough, and it was also marred by the continous presence of a character whose remarks towards the player were more cringe inducing than story-building.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												One of the best sequel a game could ever had: Valve once again proved that despite the long waiting time they do make sure that once they put up a game, its a quality work and its indeed true for the Half Life series. Very good continuation of the original story, Episode One takes the player and doesnt let down until the end, with its fantastic, adrenalin-pumping story and for the first time featuring Alyx too among Gordon Freeman and how their relationship evolves during the game, thanks to the absolutly well done character rag-doll animating.This game is a must buy for all the Half Life series fan. Despite being quite short, it stands up quite well for what it is and absolutly worth its price
