content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												Half-Life 2: Episode One. I guess you can say....It's a HALF-Sequal. Admit it...you smiled a little....Smile for Gaben's sake you ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. So this sort of half sequal to the game is very short game. It's five bucks right now, but I say it's worth it. Kind-of. I am in the middle between Yes and No to recommending this. It's short and it's not as hard as I expected. Or maybe that's just the love of Half Life 2 talking. Gameplay: Same as the old one. Graphics: Better than Half Life 2. When I first entered the game and saw Alyx's face. I was smiling because it was more HD than HL2. But those effects start wearing off after I started focusing on the gameplay. But I have to admit I did was in awe here and there after the effects seemed to have rolled off.Music: Great as always in my opinion.Why should I not buy this game?It's very short. So you have TWO (bad joke) options if you like HL2. Get the game or watch a guy complete it on youtube. If you dont mind watching it on Youtube. Watch it on Youtube! If you mind, you should get the game.Ending statements:It's up to you. I am in the middle of this so I cant really say what you should pick. Watch it on Youtube or get the game. *Gaben voice* Thanks! And have fun!

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Only play this for the storyline or if you're a hardcore HL fan. There's only a couple chapters (the last one is just a teaser for HL2: ep.2), the order in which you aquire guns is way outa' whack (you only get the crowbar towards the end of the game), and the "Lowlife" (third chapter) levels are more of an annoyance than a theme. There's only one gunship and strider in this game that you get to fight and in terms of new enemies, all you get is the zombine. Going back to the lack of chapters, I'd like to point out that even if you're not speedrunning, you can beat this game in about three hours.Why this gets an 80+ MetaCritic rating I have no idea. I'd give it a 6/10; VALVE really messed this one up.

Posted: December 10, 2015
												Half-Life was a real good game and Half-Life 2 improved on it so much.But this Episode didn't even try to 'revolutionize' the Half-Life franchise.I love Half-Life but this Episode's gameplay felt like a direct copy-paste of Half-Life 2...The story was fine I actually felt like that was the cake but for a franchise built up around revolution it didn't fill the gap between Half-Life 2 and the game I am currently playing (guess what it is) which I am particularly enjoying so i'd say if you are playing the games from Half-Life to Blue Shift to Opposing Force to Half-Life 2 etc you would have to play it but if your playing Half-Life not for the story than it's worth passing over.Post-Script: if my time spent in this game seems a little off it is because I played it offline.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												I have recently played HL2 for the first time and I hated it. I heard so many good things about it, but couldn't like it at all. Of course, the game is dated. I've got HL ep. 1 & 2  at the same time and now I'm playing this game and I hate it again. I want to play it because I don't like having games on my steam that I haven't touched, but this game frustrates me. I'm only at the beginning, but the girl (whatever her name is) is so annoying. She's comepletely useless and stands always in the way and takes to long to open a door. With only the gravity gun (first part of game) to kill the enemies, the game is slow and not fun for me. I hope the game changes this up a lot, because if this keeps on going like it does now, I won't finish this game and never start ep. 2. The game takes a lot (almost everything) from HL2, so if you liked that game, I guess you'll like this one as well. I know the half life franchise is a fan-favorite of many gamers, but for me, it's not good. There are way better shooters out there.

Posted: November 27, 2013
												I really was wainting a better game. it pains me talk like that of a Half Life game, but that is the truth. This game 2 hours playing and all I can say is, the plot is boring, you just run through a ruined factory, or whatever, using only the gravity gun. For God sake, why you need to pass more than one hour using only the gravity gun, what sucks as a weapon, when every enemy is using a machine gun?!! Their weapons simple vanish preventing you from getting it. The gravity gun should be like the kinetic in Dead Space, a bad and slow weapon used only you are out of ammo, just like the classic crowbar. If you only will give me only the bad weapon, give me my crowbar! And when you finally get you gun, the alien zombie enemies, that don't shoot you, begins to appears. It means, the game can have you using the gravity gun against armed soldiers, but you need a gun to fight unarmed aliens. Very logical!Half Life 1 is one of the best games I ever played, I really though that Half Life 2 was inferior into everything, with exception of graphics, than the first one, but still playable, beatable and funny. But this third one, is too weak, it is boring, have parts the that♥♥♥♥♥♥you off. For exemple, the part of elevator that wreckage falls from the ceiling, and you are supose to shoot that before it falls, but they end uo falling and breaking the elevator too fast for you to get a shock orb (or whatever that is) and shoot them in the falling wreckage, and the gravity gun has too little range to shoot them directly in time. I needed to repeat that many time until I finally got the way, and the next part, you are supose to grab a computer out of the way with the gravity and shoot a shock orb, but there is no indication that you can grab that, and that is a major flaw of the gravity gun, you never know when you can shoot the gravity repeller, or grab any thing, and when it decides you can shoot, doesn't mean you can grab, this takes me to other part of the game that sucks, when the train crashes. There you can shoot anywhere, but can grab nothing, I needed a walkthrough to figure out that I needed to grab the soldier that was attacking the girl, and drag him out for she to escape, until there I was only shooting him, what more should I think? The gun shoots, the thing is attacking, so shoot him.Anyway, being Half Life doesn't make a good game, the Valve should had it tested to the end before launching, and correcting this problems, and rethink the idea.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												You would think that a game of this age would be nearly bug free, however not even 20 minutes into the game a player can experiance a game breaking glitch which can ruin the entire experiance. Valve has known this glitch exists(as its all over the web) yet they have elected to do absolutely nothing regarding it. So overall, you might not get past the first 20 minutes without resetting, reinstalling, and reconfiguring the game... Good job Valve.However, having 100 percented the game I can offer a more in depth look into the game, while always offering the classical challenge of the Half-Life series, this game seems to ease the burdon on the challenge as the first whole level of the game you have the one shot grav gun, after that there isnt much a challenge with te shotgun.A third aspect is that the game was overall short, it took me four hours for the storyline but after that with the action moments of the game, it just feels like there wasnt a long in-depth playthrough but rather a 30 minute short film... Overall, I would say wait for Half-Life 3, but since that will never exist you should buy this anyway.

												The story of Half-Life gets even deeper with this part 1 mini-series, or episode 1 (Or, you know, not HL3).  This game takes place literally seconds after where we're left off in HL2.  The game feels like Half-Life 2, which feels good to begin with.  Valve offers yet another great sub-story to support the main Black Mesa story.  The objective?  To escape the quickly dying City 17.  The final boss just makes it feel like another enemy in the game who you're defeating to advance to your next challenge.  Except, your next challenge doesn't take place until the next episode (or HL3, Pt. 2, except not HL3 because Gabe Newell doens't know how to please an audience).  So, as you look back at the crumbling Citadel, just remember that (insert another overused HL3 joke here).

Posted: November 30, 2013
												This review contains spoilers regarding Half-Life 2.Riding on the high octane ending of Half-Life 2 and acting as a direct continuation, Half-Life 2: Episode One manages to be a safe, if not fulfilling, addition to the Half-Life series.Sticking with the known working formula, in Half-Life 2: Episode One you resume control of Gordon Freeman. Throwing the ending of that game to one side, Gordon finds himself back in City 17 with Alyx and a Citadel on the verge of leveling the entire city. Throughout this episode you venture back into the Citadel to contain the core and then proceed to try and escape City 17 before its destruction.The issue with this game is it brings very little new to the table. The environments are all rehashes of what was seen in HL2 - the Citadel, the streets and buildings of City 17. The only original feeling portion of the game is where you have to fight through a hospital, constantly being assaulted by Combine and Zombies, with an assault ship opening fire through any window you pass by. Amongst the zombie horde is a new creature: the Zombine. This headcrabbed Combine soldier is stronger and faster than the other zombies, possessing the ability to pull grenades out in a kamikaze run. It spices up the variety little, but only a little, for the most aprt they still act like everything else you've encountered so far. The sections with the Citadel are interesting; now a degenerating and highly unstable building that the Combine are fleeing, but ultimately it's not too indifferent from the final stages of HL2.The final, and largest, criticism is the length. This game can be completed in roughly five hours. For a game that offers little advancement in plot, instead focusing mainly on combat, there's not a lot here to make it an essential play. Don't get me wrong, it's worth playing if not just to have an excuse to dip back into the HL2 world, but this game struggles to have any sort of re-playability value when HL2 does everything this game does - only better.

Posted: July 3, 2014
												Whilst being a confusing and wordy title, It's fortunate that Valve decided to name their sequel 'Episode One' because its obvious that HL2Ep1 isn't a full-blown sequel the same way Half Life 2 was. Half Life 2 was a gamechanger the same way Half Life 1 was. It further pushed the almagamation of gameplay and storytelling whilst expanding even more on the open-ended, dynamic gameplay system HL1 introduced. The Source Engine was unlike anything ever seen before, and to this day no game has toyed with physics like HL2. Obviously HL2Ep1 couldn't do this all again after just one year. But, whilst the game is still very much worth your time, it's lacking and could have been so much better. Alarm bells ring from the start as you find yourself back in the Citadel with an overcharged Gravity Gun throwing Combine around. Didn't we do this in the last game? Then we lead a group of resistance fighters around City 17 as war breaks out, then we battle a single gunship, and for an encore we fight a solitary Strider as the final boss. (Remember in HL2 when we battled over three Striders at once?)There are some notable stabs of inspiration, however. Whilst the third chapter in the abandoned subway is a glorified sewer level, the last section where Alyx and Gordon must fight a large wave of zombies in the pitch black is sufficiently claustrophobic and tense. The part in the hospital is also fun for the same reasons. Where the game really shines is with Alyx. There's a reason why she's on the cover of this game, and that's because its really her game. We see her go through a variety of emotions throughout, all of which builds her as a likeable and necessary character. Along with Elizabeth from 'Bioshock Infinite', she's one of the most useful and unobtrusive companions in gaming. I think the reason why I like the part in the hospital is because of the strange thrill I got pumping shotgun shells into zombies whilst Alyx stood beside me doing the same. Also, I highly reccomend going for the 'One Free Bullet' achievement. Valve originally didn't want to give the player weapons until the third act of the game, hence the amount of throwable objects lying around levels (free tip: Radiators are the best weapon in the game. Always have a radiator to hand). They decided this was too limiting for the player, so after the first hour you immediately trip over a gun and cannot proceed until you've shot the lock off a door. But, of course, this doesn't stop the player from using the Gravity gun all the time anyway - and this self-imposed restriction is emergent gaming heaven. Fights turn from fast-paced if repetitive skirmishes into frantic, tactical puzzle solving....except the puzzle is always 'should I throw the computer monitor or the radiator?' This is also when Alyx shines, because often you need to rely on her to pick away at enemies whilst you distract them by tossing furniture. As you can imagine, this method of gameplay also creates many unintentional moments of comedy as you stack all the radiators and computer monitors in a pile ready for the next wave of enemies whilst Alyx looks on, quietly judging. Of course, you still need to use your rocket launcher....I found out the hard way that radiators don't work on Striders...Unlike Episode 2, which despite a slow start morphed into an excellent game that felt like the sequel we'd been waiting for (remember that final battle? And the moment right after?) this game feels much more like an expansion pack. Not in an 'Opposing Force' way, but in a 'Blue Shift' way. It's fun, but only because its more of the same.

												I played Episode One for the first time last month for like an hour and forgot about it till I completed it in a single playthrough yesterday. All I can say is, and I don't want to get slaughtered for this, I was pretty underwhelmed. Maybe it's the short campaign with very little significance to the storyline. Yeah, well you got some data you weren't supposed to see and now you need to hoof till the train station battling hoards of enemies. That's the plot in one sentence. Not much happened here, but the only reason I am underwhelmed is because I expected much more reading other reviews. It was a decent additional content to the main game, and Episode Two is supposed to be way better, so looking forward to it.Gameplay wise, if you liked Half-Life 2, you won't find any difference here. Graphics are marginally better with HDR, I guess. We've come too far to even notice the difference anyway. But we don't play Half-Life games for the graphics, do we?Overall, I'd recommend it for maintaining the continuity and for storyline reasons.

Posted: July 16, 2015
 Like half-life 2, Half-Life 2: Episode One is a physics puzzle story based action shooter involving aliens and zombies.  How can you mess that up? Well my friend, prepare to be baffled about how bad this game is compared to half life two! Im not the person to say that sequels suck, but I would think It would be hard to screw up a simple puzzle shooter using the same exact engine. This game does not feature hints on what to do on most of the missions like half life two does. The game knows it is short and it makes every mission drawn out so bad that the missions are not enjoyable. The difficulty settings do little to no difference on difficulty. All it does is weaken you and strengthen the enemy. That itself is a great way for diffculty but no matter what difficulty you are on the drawn out missions will kill you due to infinately spawning enemies (Not all the time but alot of the time) And striders. Striders..... No matter what difficulty the don't miss. Also the common talk the citizens make are just plain not needed or needs to be toned down. Every 30 seconds they say something. You stuck? TOO BAD! This game unlike half like two gives little to no hints! Yup, No enviromental hints, nobody saying anything. If you are stuck you need a walkthrough! Who likes going to a video sharing sight and listening to a young kid talk about a generic game that mainly uses blocks while doing a walkthrough on Half-Life 2: Episode one? But i digress... Half-Life 2: Episode One Is a solid 4/10

Posted: July 10, 2015
												Going into Half-Life 2: Episode 1, I was very enthusiastic to learn what happens after the ending of Half-Life 2. The beginning really showed a realistic starting point after the ending of Half-Life 2. The gameplay, to my opinion, was more fun in Episode 1 than in the first game, Half-Life 2. The storyline was very entertaining, and it's pretty fun to play as an illegal immigrant...sort of...escaping from the place you were to stay. Think of it like leaving North Korea. The ending (no spoilers ahead, read on) wasn't an ending I expected. But I guess we learn what happens next in Episode 2. If you played Half-Life 2 and are considered purchasing the episodes, you really should. The storyline is great, and remember how good these games are. This is the reason Valve games are amazing. You will enjoy this game and the rest of the Series.

Posted: March 31, 2016
												Any followup to Half-Life 2 would have some pretty high expectations but fortunately most of them were met with Episode One which is short but extremely sweet. We get to see more of City 17, an unstable Citadel and Alyx, whose roll has been greatly expanded. She's completely believable and playing alongside her is fantastic. The animation and HDR visual effects are also very well done and an impressive step up from the original game.Valve had a great idea. Instead of making us wait for one big game to be finished they came up with doing episodic installments. More content more often. Unfortunately they stopped after two episodes and we've been on hold for 8 years but that's another story.

Posted: January 2, 2015
												It's alright. It certainly felt like a Half-Life game, but at the same time it just felt a bit lacking. There was practically nothing new added in this expansion, and in turn ended up feeling like a story expansion rather than a gameplay expansion. Practically half of the game felt boring to me, and that's really disappointing considering how the first two games had me in a constant state of wonder and amusement throughout their entire durations. However, the good parts were great; and the final boss, as brief as it was, felt like a throwback to how Half-Life 1's style of boss fights and was enjoyable. Only get this if you've played the other Half-Life games. This is not for newcomers as it will leave you feeling like you were missing out on a lot. On the other hand, if you are a fan of Half-Life. chances are you've already played this expansion.

Posted: May 1, 2015
												Score: 10/10If you are a fan of the Half Life series and bought HL2 (Half Life 2) then you will enjoy HL2 Episode 1. In this episode we see the continuation of the story of Gordon Freeman from the end of HL2. Without spoiling any thing I’ll say that this episode takes the ideas from HL2 and turns them up to 11.There are one or two new tweaks to weapons from HL2. There are some new threats and new scripted events. The overall story is Alyx and Gordon have to stop another catastrophe and escape. They meet rebel groups along the way. They have to fight familiar foes in a new context and in new puzzles. The story here is very intriguing. I won’t say more so as not to spoil the surprises but I will say be ready for the giant bugs and be aggressive.-	Enjoy.

Posted: February 13, 2011
												Half-Life 2: Episode One takes place right after Half-Life 2, and was a begining of an experiment of getting out the Half Life 2 continuations faster... which ended up falling on it's♥♥♥♥♥when Valve realised that after Portal and TF2, no one cared about Half Life anymore, the final nail on the coffin being when valve discovered they could make more money off of selling virtual items for F2P games and promoting e-sports crap than Half Life could ever hope of doing.Anyways, Episode One is a huge graphical leap from Half Life 2, adding in pretty HDR effects (even though you're going to see a lot of warm colors in this game) and exploring more of the physics based gameplay. One complaint is that it feels pretty short and does feel like you're essentially doing more of the same you did in the last parts of Half Life 2, only in reverse.  You also get commentary, which always a great thing to listen to.Overall, get this game if you played/own Half Life 2 and haven't played Episode one yet

Posted: August 27, 2015
												Pretty much Half-Life 2, with more of the story to follow up on. While this game is a tad easier than Half-Life 2 (but not by much), it seems a little less in my eyes than Half-Life 2 itself. Does it follow up well? Sure. Does it continue the story well? I think so. So what do I think is lesser? Probably the amount of time you play this installment. I onky got in three square hours, but I'm sure other people have gotten in an hour and a half. I know the title says "Episode One" (implying that it would be shorter), but I just wanted the keep playing, especially after the ending I got in this episode. I could see it more of a continuation for people who just finished Half-Life 2. I only finished it about a month ago, and coming back to it for only three hours, while enjoyable, still left me wanting more. I still recommend it to anyone who wants good story and good gameplay combined to make a trule unique, and enjoyable experience- like the other two Half-Life games.

Posted: August 27, 2015
												Pretty much Half-Life 2, with more of the story to follow up on. While this game is a tad easier than Half-Life 2 (but not by much), it seems a little less in my eyes than Half-Life 2 itself. Does it follow up well? Sure. Does it continue the story well? I think so. So what do I think is lesser? Probably the amount of time you play this installment. I onky got in three square hours, but I'm sure other people have gotten in an hour and a half. I know the title says "Episode One" (implying that it would be shorter), but I just wanted the keep playing, especially after the ending I got in this episode. I could see it more of a continuation for people who just finished Half-Life 2. I only finished it about a month ago, and coming back to it for only three hours, while enjoyable, still left me wanting more. I still recommend it to anyone who wants good story and good gameplay combined to make a trule unique, and enjoyable experience- like the other two Half-Life games.

Posted: June 4, 2016
												Flawless game design that has barely aged from when it was released more than ten years ago. Be warned though, the pacing starts slow but heats up later in the game. The game starts with a focus on puzzle solving before you get to the more traditional shooting everything in the face. Graphics still look good, textures still look clean and you will likely get ridiculously high frame rates on any modern computer, which makes it a perfect candidate for playing in 3d where it looks amazing. It is a short game at about 4 hours long, but those hours are packed with some of the finest gameplay and atmosphere that many newer games could only wish for. The only negative about the Half Life series is that it makes me want Half Life 3.

Posted: June 4, 2015
												Half-Life 2: Episode One is yet another single-player FPS from Valve that came out in 2006 year. It's a direct continuation to Half-Life 2 and supposedly a start of episodic releases. If forget that it never got past Episode Two. Episodic releases of games just never work, unless you are Telltale.It's quite similiar to Half-Life 2 and uses game design philosophy behind it, as well as gameplay. And assets. So there isn't much to explain. A fancy shooter with gravigun. Only this time you often has a teammate, Alyx, who doesn't die easily.Plotwise it continues where Half-Life 2 ends, as you are found in rumbles of a citadel of City 17. Now it's your mission to get out from city and cause trouble for yourself in meanwhile.It starts out quite weak, as you have to venture through some amount of storyline scenes and then left with super-charged gravigun. Super-charged gravigun was quite a nice surprise at the end of Half-Life 2, but here it overstays it's welcome, as it's the only weapon you can use, with no variety.It gets better after first two chapter, as you slowly gain standard weapons, find much more creative uses for gravigun and will get to enjoy Alyx's fighting company much more, while you are exploring dark underground, ruins of a city and hospital. Hospital also featured some AI vs AI fights, something that me and many players love watching. And boss. Same old in new enviroment.Episode One adds a big new feature in Valve games for first time: Developers commentary.When activated, the flying icons will appear in the levels that you can use. Upon usage you will be listening (and reading in subtitles) to one of the developers talking about something related or unrelated to where the icon was placed. It could be Alyx's AI, or changes in lighting, or the way that scene came to be, or just how smart they count themselves.It's quite a great addition and is much better than Developer Commentaries in later Valve games, which was more like Voice Acting Commentary: How Amazing It Is To Have No Script.Overall, it's a decent FPS. Decent episode. Something that you will beat, have fun and then forget. Still nice.

Posted: June 4, 2015
												As usual , Valve has another amazing game on its hands. It always baffles me that they can create a game that is visually impressive and run amazingly smooth even on the lowest of the settings. The story is great; some lovely, touching moments, and some hilarious ones (here's looking at you Dr Kleiner) and keeps all the same characters you run into along the way. Definitely a great game and segway into the next one (episode 2). Plus the achievements are not too hard to get (can play on easy), especially since you can save where ever and as often as you like.  10/10 keep doing what your doing valve! :)

												Alyx and D0g and that's all you really need to know.  A continuation of the original it takes the franchise forward in a way no DLC pack could ever accomplish.  The graphics are slightly better than HL2 which is expected for a title released 2 years after it but none of the action or charm has been lost.  There are puzzles to be solved throughout and any Portal player will recognize the tech.  Sometimes challenging, sometimes maddening until a quick trip to YouTube gives you that a-ha! moment.  You can't call yourself a Half Life fan unless you play this game.

												Oh come on... What's not to love about Half Life 2:EP1??It may be a short game,. but hell, the Half Life series are just epic. Shame it reverts to the ZePEFiM..I found the train station level suitably challenging, and had me going back for a few rounds to see if I could do things any faster.The game ends where HL2:EP2 kicks off, and why shouldn't it? So wake up and . . smell the ashes again. .

Posted: May 22, 2015
												Episode 1 is the nice, short and sweet sequel to Half Life 2 that essentially more or less gives us answers as to the sudden and very cliffhanger-esque conclusion of the second game in the Half Life series.  Besides perhaps some extra technical updages and level design not much new is seen in this sequel, however even when recycling their assets Valve managed to deliver in terms of story and fun gameplay, giving us another round with the overpowered uber gravity gun that marked the highlight of the game's finale as well as throw in some extra suspense.One thing I will mention is how much I liked the short, episodic way they unveiled this 'sequel' of sorts.  It gave a relatively inexpensive means to continue the story without putting a lot of stress on the dev teams who likely also had other things to do.  Like the original Portal, it was short enough to be almost considered an intern project, but well developed enough that it had the nice spit and polish of a fully professionally-made triple A title (back when the term didn't just restrict to game price and graphic output and actually referred to the quality of the overall game).  In a way it's kind of like seeing an expansion pack of sorts to the original, and I like that.Not much else to say.  If you were a fan of Half Life 2 and don't own this one yet (which I don't know why) it is definitely worth purchasing along with the next one.

Posted: May 13, 2015
												Don't just stand there Gordon. Pick up that crowbar, again, again.Combined with Half-Life: Episode 2 this makes for a great expansion to HL2. Some of the combat situations in these new episodes are more exciting then in HL2.The only problem is that Episodes 4 and 5 (with a possible 6) were all cancelled in favor of non-HL games and hat sales. Meanwhile Episode 3 has been stuck in limbo since 2007.Valve has set an extremely high quality standard that many of us appreciate, unfortunately it has been so long that many feel Valve are now afraid to release any version of Episode 3 or HL3 due to consumer expectations being so high.Projects such as Counterstrike, Black Mesa, Sven Co-op and hundreds of other expansive HL-related mods show that eventually the fans will get tired of waiting and make their own games. If Episode 3/HL3 take much longer I see the fans taking the reins and continuing the story.Anyways, HL is one of, if not the, best FPS series of all time. Do yourself a favor if you have never played them and start with HL1 and/or Black Mesa. Follow up with Opposing Force, Blue Shift, & Decay. Then play HL2 & these two Episodes, then the Portal games which tie in story-wise.

Posted: November 25, 2014
												The most unfortunately short sequel of all time. Episode One takes many of the best parts of Half Life 2 and distills them to their essential core, giving you one hell of a three-ish hour journey. Valve really learned a lot of lessons between the previous game and this one, but it cuts itself incredibly short. The first time I played through this, way back when, I was actually really mad when everything suddenly came to a close before it even felt like it started. Considering that it is easy to get 15 or so hours out of the first game, this was a huge kick to the stomach... but it was still fun.This game is like listening to Stairway to Heaven and cutting it off before the guitar solo. I mean, it's awesome, but... why stop it there?With the added bonus of being able to hop to Episode 2 right away, it isn't so bad... but still.

												This sequel has been criticized by many, but it's not really that bad at all in my opinion.Of course, the lack of new weapons is a mishap, the levels aren't really that much of a challenge and constantly teaming up with Alyx throughout the entire game gets boring also after a while, especially because she's quite a sharp shooter.But, there is enough to enjoy in this short adventure. Starting right after the moment you destroyed the core in HL2 you are sent on a mission to evacuate from City 17 as soon as possible, saving as much citizens as you can throughout the game.The levels itself are more straight forward then the levels were at HL2, but still enough fights are worth playing through the linear pathways. 												Nice edition to the Half-Life franchise. The story continued where the last game left off, and it's just as good as always. It was something to look forward to. However, with people around you all the time, it can get a little claustrophobic - mainly because the AI isn't great and there are a lot of narrow tunnels. No notable graphic or musical leaps from HL2, it was mostly the same.There wasn't a lot of gameplay (3.5 hours), but it was worth the money.

Posted: January 29, 2015
												Mäng on mul tegelikult juba ammu läbi. Ei saa midagi halba öelda, sest tegu on siiski Half-Life`i seeria jätkuga. Mäng pole nii uus (2006), kuid siiski pakub seda siiani ja ka edaspidigi mängitavust. Graafika on hea nagu ikka Source Enginil töötaval mängul kohane on. Half-Life 2: Episode One`l on ka jätk Episode Two, mille olen ka läbi mänginud. Pikkamisi oodatakse Half-Life 3, mis tuleb kindlasti hea, aga ootaks graafikaliselt midagi enamat. Tulles tagasi korra Episode One`i juurde tagasi, siis sa kehastad Gordon Freeman`i ning seikled pärast eelmises osas (Half-Life 2) sõjast räsitud City 17 linnas. Tegelikult pead sealt pääsema. Muidugi aitab sind terve seikluse aja Alyx Vance. Nagu ma juba ütlesin, et on olemas Episode Two, siis seal toimub seiklus pärast City 17`st pääsemist. Nii palju võin öelda, et Episode Two`s on loodust palju rohkem ning toodud on mitmeid erinevaid külasid. Olen mänginud läbi Black Mesa, Half-Life 2, Half-Life 2: Episode One ja Half-Life 2: Episode Two. Episode One võttis minul aega esimesel korral 4h. Nüüd mängin selle uuesti läbi.Soovitan Half-Life seeriat mängida, kui pole nii head arvutit või kui selle taoline mäng üldse meeldib. Kusjuures Black Mesa on tasuta Half-Life, mis pole küll lõpuni valmis, kuid mis köidab oma uskumatu Half-Life 2 mootoriga. Nii, et tõmba see juba täna ning naudi Half-Life`i esimest osa koos Half-Life 2 graafikaga.

Posted: January 25, 2015
												Some people say better late than never, so here are my thoughts about the game.Half Life 2 Episode One is a direct sequel to the 2004 game Half Life 2. A rather controversial option to spilt the sequel into an episodic format was taken by Valve to ease up the wait for the final product, given their previous track record with their games. So, this option did work?Long story short, yes and no. First of all, given the lenght of the previous game, it's a dissapointment to see this game end up in almost four hours (and that's if you take your time or play in higher difficulties), and the overall game doesn't change too much the formula of things.On the other hand, it's more of the really well made shooter of 2004 and that's always a good thing and it wraps up nicely as a direct sequel of the second game of the saga.Some points to discuss, some of them with minor spoilers so be careful with that:Gameplay: It's Half Life. The shooting, while it may be not very good for some people, it's functional and provides a sense of weight to each weapon which makes the overall gameplay fun. There are some 'interactive cinematics' moments but thankfully they don't derail much of the overall product. A gripe that I have with this point is the lack of new weapons. The Gravity Gun is once again the spotlight of the game and comes back as resourceful as ever, but then again, you get the upgrade at the beggining of the game and then it's taken off from you almost immediatly. I really wanted to see the OP Gravity Gun in action on the outskirts of the Citadel.Story: It's good. Not great but good. Basically it all boils down to 'Escape City 17 as soon as possible because everything is gonna explode like real fast' and it doesn't change that much. Sure, it serves as a catalyst for things to come, but it's something explored better in the second episode. I'll give this a pass because it's the start of a trilogy. You can't throw nonsensical twists or a complex plot at the start of a seasonal game, you'll make things too confusing for no good reason.Difficulty: Rather easy, as with the second game it's because of the Gravity Gun. It makes things way too easy sometimes and in certain occasions you can discard your weapons entirely if you come across a car engine or something with similar weight, it one shots almost everything in sight. One fun thing to do it's play with the achievement 'The One Free Bullet' in mind, it makes the whole game more intense.Overall: Yes, it's a good game with a few shortcomings, but most of them are the standard ones with a trilogy in mind.

Posted: June 13, 2013
												Episode One has as bad a rap as a Half Life game can get. At its best, Ep. 1 is seen as more of the same; at its worst, filler. What Ep. 1 is to Your Humble Narrator is a brilliantly nuanced return to form to the older games in the series: a very minimalist story, but great atmosphere. Add in some superb gameplay, with better level design and smarter puzzles than seen in HL2, and the fact that Alex is to this day the best supporting character in a video game and Episode One has more than earned its place in the Half Life pantheon.

Posted: February 22, 2014
												Half-Life 2: Episode OneStory (8/10):The story of Half-Life 2: Episode One plays on from the original Half-Life 2.Therefore, in order to fully understand the logic of the story, the original Half-Life 2 should be played.Half-Life 2: Episode One's story spans over five chapters, immersing the player with original characters and enemies.As explained in the Developer's Commentary, there are admittedly some sequences where dialogue is too long and ruins some crucial parts of the story.Although, the story does run well with the five chapters and the ending will possibly leave you wanting the next Episode in the series.Overall, Half-Life 2: Episode One has a good storyline and a few boring non-interactive dialogue moments here and there.Game play (8/10):The game play of Half-Life 2: Episode One is fluent and rewarding.Whilst progressing through the storyline, there are pieces of equipment acquired after reaching specific points.These rewards are motivating and is enough to push the player towards the conclusion of the game.Within this game the player will encounter many weapons from the original games, like the iconic crowbar.The combat system in conjunction with weapons is a fluent mix and certain game play mechanics like the flashlight capacity, intensifies certain levels.Also included within the levels is a variety of environmental objects that are interactive and combat effective.These environmental objects are used to create smart solutions to simple problems.In this case, Half-Life 2: Episode One's game play is constructive and destructive, making an enjoyable experience.Graphics (10/10):The graphics of Half-Life 2: Episode One is outstanding for it's time.This game has perfect settings for graphic options, from Shader Detail to High Dynamic Range.The lighting and detail of the sprites within the game looks realistic and it immerses the player into the environment.Guns, environmental objects, enemies and everything included looks like real design was incorporated when producing.Explained within the Developer's Commentary, many environment objects were based off real creations and it is reconstructed effectively.In other words, the game developers made the environment look realistic and it is a true accomplishment for the time period for when it was development.Audio (7/10):The audio of Half-Life 2: Episode One is realistic but the soundtrack doesn't immerse the player.Whilst playing through the story, combat and exploring situations included music that wasn't exciting enough.Although, the environmental, character, enemy and gun tracks included did give a sense of presence.The sounds when an enemy has acquired a target, a mine has exploded or if a zombie is nearby was executed well.If the player listens closely they can recognise footsteps and the direction of any sound.In conclusion, the games soundtrack is mildly boring but the environmental sounds are good. Additional Features (8/10):In Half-Life 2: Episode One there is an additional feature that many previous players of Valve games could recognise, the Developer's Commentary.This feature of the game becomes unlocked once the completion of a desired chapter is registered.The Developer's Commentary provides an inside look on the previous and/or designs, ideas and game play mechanics considered throughout the development of the game.This is encoded using floating speech bubble sprites spread across the five chapters in their appropriate positions.Also, once a commentary is being played, the player becomes invincible to enemy damage and can sometimes freeze the enemies themselves to state an idea.This additional feature is a productive way of expressing the developer's ideas and explaining the nature of the game.After completing the game, it is recommended to try the Developer's Commentary for an in-depth explanation on the games features and aesthetics.Overall (8.2/10)

Posted: October 13, 2016
What I liked about the game •	More half-life 2. Nothing has changed for the worst; everything is still top-notch, like characters, game play, level design, and soundtrack.•	In Half-life 2 episode one you get to explore more of the Citadel. You also get to explore new locations in city 17.•	Steam achievements. Try and have a go at the one free bullet achievement, where you can only fire one bullet and for the rest of the game you have to use the Gravity gun, the rocket launcher, grenades, and crowbar.       What I disliked about the game •	Not a lot of new content like new weapons or characters. There are no driving sections in the game. No new environments, In Half-life 2 there was the coast and Ravenholm, but in episode one you're mostly stuck in city 17. •	 The game is too short; it took me only 4 hours to complete.•	Still no answered questions; in fact brings up more questions.  ConclusionA brilliant sequel to the half-life 2. If you really enjoyed half-life 2, I highly recommend you buy this. 90/100

Posted: January 1, 2014
												The episodic approach at story telling seems to work very well at shoring up the short comings of the base Half-Life 2's story. It forces the telling of a specific, condensed narrative, and consequently seems to have provided more story in its short life than the main game did otherwise. Episode 1 has the added bonus of utilizing the most entertaining game play mechanics of the main game, specifically the empowered gravity gun, which is sure to bring a gleeful smile to a gamer's lips.

Posted: October 25, 2013
												Following on excellently from HL2, and the exact same atmosphere still inducing shivers up the spine, this acts as the epilogue to the events of Nova Prospekt and City 17. Perhaps some areas were lacking in the way they failed to introduce a new aspect to the equation (judging how much of it is similar to the street combat from the previous), however the venturing into the dark underground, into the core of the citadel and outside City 17 really summarises the past story arc, and beautifully permits continuity for the next chapter of the story against the combine. Really, HL2 cannot be completed without this episode.

Posted: August 21, 2011
												A sequel to a sequel thats the first episode of a series in a series... so confused. This game doesn't feel like a flow blown sequel but rather an extremely large standalone DLC episode. The game is rather short, but everything feels polished. There is all the best the series has to offer in here. The game is entirely based around escaping from City 17, which is now falling apart. This game expands the story, gives you new enemies to face, and throws you into unique lsituations in various locations. The biggest feature is that you are with Alyx nearly the whole game. She is a great character and while she takes away from the ambience of being alone, her AI is great so she is never useless or annoying. This game feels like a set up for bigger things to come, but this game does provide plenty of fun and challenges.
